You’re overly concerned about a private company. XRP and the Ripple network exist independently of Rippleco.
They have told everybody what they plan to do. And they even locked up XRP in escrow. I’m not sure why you are freaking out. They’ve done way more than they had to. Ripple isn’t centralized.
XRP is a digital asset that Ripple holds. You can also hold this digital asset. You are now 2 separate entities that have something in common -you both hold XRP. Nothing more.
Ripple does not sell XRP to consumers. You purchased it from somebody else, like an exchange.
$ XRP is on-demand liquidity. Market makers provide liquidity. Banks provide volume. All have been invited to join RippleNet. pic.twitter.com/7PXz50Gi0w
You did NOT purchase XRP from Ripple.
Why do you care so much how Ripple uses their XRP? People can use $ XRP for whatever they want. How people chose to use their crypto really isn’t any of your business.
Google “crypto wash trading” and you’ll understand why it’s a big deal.
Never heard of it. @JoelKatz @nbougalis , where should we go if we are wondering about the validity of a site claiming to be affiliated with Ripple? How can we check?
It’s your crypto and therefore your decision. Personally, I don’t trust exchanges. It’s normally just a matter of time before they get “hacked.”

Bitcoin found a way to eliminate trusted 3rd parties. Eliminating intermediaries was literally the breakthrough. By trusting Coinbase, you’ve brought the trusted 3rd party right back into the equation.
This isn’t about banks or fiat. It’s about having control over your crypto or giving somebody else complete control. Giving that control away defeats the whole purpose of crypto, IMO.

This is from 2014. Give it a read and you’ll see right away how much things have changed. The vision described here is why I evangelized Bitcoin for many years. https:// dealbook.nytimes.com/2014/01/21/why -bitcoin-matters/ …

I am unbanked and had been relying on Bitcoin until it became completely unusable to me. I can’t afford $40 txn fees. Bitcoincash is just like Bitcoin used to be all of those years.
Exchanges are, for the most part, uninsured. Over 910,000 Bitcoin have been stolen from them over the years and users are generally SOL.

Ripple could go public but I have no idea why they would ever do that. They have a $15 BILLION + war chest and they could still do a late investment round if they wanted/needed. Going public means giving the public a say in operations/direction and that’s rarely helpful.

For regular wallets, Coinbase has complete control over your keys. That’s why Coinbase users where not able to receive their BitcoinCash until recently and they almost didn’t receive it all. Coinbase originally said no and then backpedaled after the fury.
Ripple stock isn’t available for purchase.

Bitcoin mining is the most raw, price-driven marketplace in the world. If those surpluses make the price of power in such places cheaper than anywhere else, miners will move there.

Sounds like important work. My point is that rising crypto prices will incentivize even more rapid advances in generation, storage and distribution networks, whether in solar, nuclear, or fossil fuels. That counters the simplistic bitcoin-will-destroy-the-planet narrative.

I should clarify: For the space fans out there, sadly I won't be touching on the otherwise intriguing idea of outer-space mining (though I think they are coming) but on the positive impact that a rising bitcoin price could have in incentivizing solar energy innovation.
